The Excellence in Mental Health and Addiction Treatment Expansion Act of 2019 will expand the #CCBHC program to even more states and ensure the existing clinics have the funding they need.

If funding for CCBHCs expires, over 50% of CCBHCs will have to re-establish wait lists, eliminate services like addiction counseling or peer recovery, or close their doors to new patients. Thousands of patients will lose treatment. We can't let this happen.

Ask James Willyard, Assistant Chief of Police, Pryor Creek Police: "I strongly support extending the CCBHC model for additional years so our community can have the resources it needs to help families and individuals get into treatment & recovery instead of jail or the hospital."

CCBHCs work. Just ask Dea Duggan, a 39 year-old mother of four, who struggled with mental health and substance abuse her whole life. After trying many clinics and relapsing 20 times, she finally found the comprehensive support she needed at a CCBHC. pic.twitter.com/yzmai235Qq

My 2014 bill, the Excellence in Mental Health and Addiction Treatment Act, was one of the most significant steps forward in community behavioral health in decades ‚Äì but now the Certified Community Behavioral Health Clinics we established are in danger of running out of funding.

A new @USGAO report shows that 70% of adults with mental health or addiction issues - nearly 40 million Americans - go completely untreated. The main reasons why? Cost, stigma, and access challenges. https://www.gao.gov/products/GAO-19-274¬†‚Ä¶
